columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the company's stock price using the weighted average cost of capital which considers how the allotment of assets are adjusted.

The weighted average cost of capital of a company refers to the rate at which  the company or firm can pay for their investors' assets. The weighted average cost of capital is a measurement of which investments should be done since the return of the investment should be at least equal to the weighted average cost of capital of the company.

From the problem, we have the following values:
| EBIT| $3,150,000| 
|--|--| 
| EBIT Growth Rate|15\% | 
| Depreciation|$265,000 | 
|Depreciation Growth Rate |20\% | 
| Net Working Capital|$105,000 | 
| Net Working Capital Growth Rate|10\% | 
| Capital Spending|$495,000 | 
| Capital Spending Growth Rate| 20\%| 
|Debt | $19,500,000| 
|Outstanding Shares | 400,000| 
| Growth of adjusted cash flow from assets|3.5\% | 
|WACC |9.25\% | 
| Tax Rate|22\% |

In order to solve this problem, we will first solve for the cash flow from Year 1 to Year 5. To do this, we will first use the given values to solve for the particulars at the start of the investment (Year 0). 

The starting earnings before interest and tax is $\$3,150,000$. To get the net income, we will multiply this to one minus the tax rate of $22\%$ or $0.22$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income}&=\$3,150,000\times (1-0.22)\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,457,000
\end{aligned}$$

The net income for Year 0 is $\$2,457,000$

We can then solve for the cash flow at Year 0 by taking the net income, adding the depreciation, and subtracting both the increase in net working capital and capital spending from it. The given values are as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$265,000\\
\text{Increase in Net Working Capital}&=\$105,000\\
\text{Capital Spending}&=\$495,000
\end{aligned}$$

From the values above, we can then solve for the cash flow of Year 0:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow at Year 0}&=\$2,457,000+\$265,000\\
&-\$105,000-\$495,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,122,000
\end{aligned}$$

The cash flow at Year 0 is $\$2,122,000$

The problem states that the earnings before interest and capital increase by $15\%$ every year. Therefore, we will take the EBIT for the previous year and multiply it to one plus the rate of increase to get the EBIT for the current year. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT for Year 1}&=\text{EBIT for Year 0} \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$3,150,000\times 1.15\\
&=\$3,622,500\\[15 pt]

\text{EBIT for Year 2}&=\text{EBIT for Year 1} \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$3,622,500 \times 1.15\\
&=\$4,165,875\\[15 pt]

\text{EBIT for Year 3}&=\text{EBIT for Year 2} \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$4,165,875 \times 1.15\\
&=\$4,790,756.25\\[15 pt]

\text{EBIT for Year 4}&=\text{EBIT for Year 3} \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$4,790,756.25 \times 1.15\\
&=\$5,509,369.69\\[15 pt]


\text{EBIT for Year 5}&=\text{EBIT for Year 4} \times (1+0.15)\\
&=\$5,509,369.69 \times 1.15\\
&=\$6,335,775.14\\[15 pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Now, from the EBIT, we can solve for the net income for all the years by multiplying the EBIT by one minus the tax rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net income for Year 1}&=\text{EBIT for Year 1} \times (1-0.22)\\
&=\$3,622,500\times 0.78\\
&=\$2,825,550\\[15 pt]

\text{Net income for Year 2}&=\text{EBIT for Year 2} \times (1-0.22)\\
&=\$4,165,875\times 0.78\\
&=\$3,249,382.5\\[15 pt]

\text{Net income for Year 3}&=\text{EBIT for Year 3} \times (1-0.22)\\
&=\$4,790,756.25\times 0.78\\
&=\$3,736,789.86\\[15 pt]

\text{Net income for Year 4}&=\text{EBIT for Year 4} \times (1-0.22)\\
&=\$5,509,369.69\times 0.78\\
&=\$4,297,308.36\\[15 pt]

\text{Net income for Year 5}&=\text{EBIT for Year 5} \times (1-0.22)\\
&=\$6,335,775.14\times 0.78\\
&=\$4,941,904.61\\[15 pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The problem also states that the depreciation and the capital spending will increase by $20\%$ per year. This means that we will take the depreciation and the capital spending from the previous year and multiply it by one plus the rate of increase.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation for Year 1}&=\text{Depreciation for Year 0} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$265,000\times 1.20\\
&=\$318,000\\[15 pt]

\text{Depreciation for Year 2}&=\text{Depreciation for Year 1} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$318,000 \times 1.20\\
&=\$381,600\\[15 pt]

\text{Depreciation for Year 3}&=\text{Depreciation for Year 2} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$381,600 \times 1.20\\
&=\$457,920\\[15 pt]

\text{Depreciation for Year 4}&=\text{Depreciation for Year 3} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$457,920 \times 1.20\\
&=\$549,504\\[15 pt]


\text{Depreciation for Year 5}&=\text{Depreciation for Year 4} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$549,504 \times 1.20\\
&=\$659,404.80\\[15 pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The same process as above will be done for the capital spending

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital Spending for Year 1}&=\text{Capital Spending  for Year 0} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$495,000\times 1.20\\
&=\$594,000\\[15 pt]

\text{Capital Spending  for Year 2}&=\text{Capital Spending  for Year 1} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$594,000 \times 1.20\\
&=\$712,800\\[15 pt]

\text{Capital Spending  for Year 3}&=\text{Capital Spending  for Year 2} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$712,800 \times 1.20\\
&=\$855,360\\[15 pt]

\text{Capital Spending  for Year 4}&=\text{Capital Spending  for Year 3} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$855,360 \times 1.20\\
&=\$1,026,432\\[15 pt]


\text{Capital Spending  for Year 5}&=\text{Capital Spending  for Year 4} \times (1+0.20)\\
&=\$1,026,432 \times 1.20\\
&=\$1,231,718.40\\[15 pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The Net Working Capital increases by $10\%$ each year so we will take the previous year's NWC and multiply it by one times the rate of increase.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Increase in NWC for Year 1}&=\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 0} \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$105,00\times 1.10\\
&=\$115,500\\[15 pt]

\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 2}&=\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 1} \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$115,500 \times 1.10\\
&=\$127,050\\[15 pt]

\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 3}&=\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 2} \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$127,050 \times 1.10\\
&=\$139,755\\[15 pt]

\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 4}&=\text{Increase in NWC for Year 3} \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$139,755 \times 1.10\\
&=\$153,730.50\\[15 pt]


\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 5}&=\text{Increase in NWC  for Year 4} \times (1+0.10)\\
&=\$153,730.50 \times 1.10\\
&=\$169,103.55\\[15 pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Now that we have the necessary values, we can now solve for the cash flow of each year by taking the net income, adding the depreciation, then subtracting the increase in net working capital as well as the capital spending.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow for Year 1}&=\$2,825,550+\$318,000\\
&-\$594,000-\$115,500\\
&=\$2,434,050\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 2}&=\$3,249,382.5+\$381,600\\
&-\$712,800-\$127,050\\
&=\$2,791,132.50\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 3}&=\$3,736,789.86+\$457,920\\
&-\$139,755-\$855,360\\
&=\$3,199,594.86\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 4}&=\$4,297,308.36+\$549,504\\
&-\$153,730.50-\$1,026,432\\
&=\$3,666,649.86\\[15 pt]

\text{Cash flow for Year 5}&=\$4,941,904.61+\$659,404.80\\
&-\$169,103.55-\$1,231,718.40\\
&=\$4,200,487.46
\end{aligned}$$

In order to get the equity value, we first need to solve for the total of the present value of the cash flows. To do this, we will multiply the given cash flows by the present value annuity rate. The following rates will be used for this:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.91533\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.83783\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.76689\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.70196\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.64253
\end{aligned}$$

To get the present value of the cash flows, we will multiply each by the given rates above:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow Year 1}&=\$2,434,050\times 0.91533\\
&=\$2,227,958.99\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value cash flow Year 2}&=\$2,791,132.50 \times 0.83783\\
&=\$2,338,494.54\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value cash flow Year 3}&=\$3,199,594.86 \times 0.76689\\
&=\$2,453,737.30\\[15 pt]

\text{Present value cash flow Year 4}&=\$3,666,649.86 \times 0.70196\\
&=\$2,573,841.54
\end{aligned}$$

For the present value of Year 5, we will take the sum of terminal value and the cash flow of Year 5 and then multiply it to the given rate above:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow Year 5}&=(\$4,200,487.46+\$75,608,774.28)\times 0.64253\\
&=\$51,279,844.95
\end{aligned}$$

Since we now have the present value cash flow for all years, we can simply add them to get the total value of cash flows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total value}&=\$2,227,958.99+\$2,338,494.54\\
&+\$2,453,737.30+\$2,573,841.54\\
&+\$51,279,844.95\\[15 pt]
&=\$60,873,877.32
\end{aligned}$$

From the total value, we can get the equity value of the company by subtracting the debt which is $\$19,500,000$.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity value}&=\$60,873,877.32-\$19,500,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$41,373,877.32
\end{aligned}$$

The equity value of the company is $\$41,373,877.32$

Now, we can solve for the price per share of the company's stock by simply dividing the equity value of the company by the number of its outstanding shares of $400,000$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price per share}&=\dfrac{\$41,373,877.32}{400,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$103.43
\end{aligned}$$

The company's shares are priced at $\$103.43$
